descriptionContent.comment: The first manga of the entry, and also one of the final bosses of doomed yuri. Thinking about it now and then, I really don't know how the author managed to use the most predictable plot and made it 10 times more emotional and captivated me as a reader. I wholeheartedly recommend this to every yuri specimen, seriously.

10 year-old me didn't have Dragon Ball as my first manga - it was this one. Considered one of the best and also near unknown shounen mangas of the 2010s, this has every aspect of storytelling done right. Some of the chapters were cryptic it confused me even when re-reading, and finding fan discussions felt like finding needles in a haystack. Now I still hold this manga in high regards in the age of JJKSlop.

name.title: Kaguya-sama wa Kokurasetai: Tensaitachi no Renai Zunousen
name.author: Akasaka Aka - 2019

descriptionContent.comment: This manga dragged me in a timeline full of events that shaped me into the man I am today. The reason I was able to make new friends without succumbing to total loneliness was because of all the joys the Discord server has brought, and I can't thank them enough. Oh, and, this manga is good, btw. The later arcs aren't as memorable as the Christmas arc but still ends on a high note.

The story contributes to human trauma and coming to terms with themselves. It's overly dramatic, but it's well-executed with stunning frames and emotional expressions. It's worth reading if you're into horror and psychological aspects, alongside some whimsy Slice of Life breather chapters.

A story full of joy and dramatic between the couple who live in separate nations holding different views towards each other with awesome character development and impeccable fanservices. Romeo to me is the realest and most relatable sigma male character, next to Hak Son.

One of the most complex manga I've ever read. The story and the flow might not keep you excited at times, and there are some weak arcs (the Kai arc), yet it has some of the most captivating moments between main characters, arch-nemesis, and mythical creatures alike.

First time reading it, I thought tragedy mangas really weren't my thing. I was young, naive, and for me it felt like a horror manga that belonged in a distant memory. Growing up and realizing your life could be easily taken into this route is horrifying. One wrong move and that's it. It's heartbreaking how, even though the world around Punpun felt big, it also felt lonely, as if his story is just one of those that will be lost in time forever.

Same as Punpun, this manga carries a lot of weight about wrong decisions, life circumstances, and struggling to let go of the past - something we all relate to when we grow up. However, the manga shows the effect in a more harrowing way, knowing that accepting the past is another way to mature, even if it's painful and you might lose yourself in the process.

A twisted manga based on CLAMP style and Junji Ito-esque horror elements. Currently stuck on how to develop the lore to be more specific, as the series keeps being cryptic about it. The horror elements, however, sometimes outshine the wacky SoL aspect this manga is also good at.
